message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of mental retardation, microcephaly, and mousy odor to breath are consistent with phenylketonuria (PKU), a rare metabolic disorder caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. PKU results in the buildup of phenylalanine and its byproducts in the blood and can lead to neurological problems if left untreated. Option B is incorrect because tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency is associated with a different disease, called dopa-responsive dystonia. Option C is incorrect because excess tetrahydrobiopterin cofactor is associated with a different metabolic disorder, called hyperphenylalaninemia. Option D is incorrect because excess phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is unlikely to cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of mental retardation, microcephaly, and mousy odor to the breath suggest the infant may have a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity, which leads to a buildup of phenylalanine and other metabolites causing these symptoms. None of the other options would lead to these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mental retardation and microcephaly suggest a developmental disorder, and the mousy odor suggests phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. Options B and C are not associated with PKU, and option D is not possible as excess activity of an enzyme is rare.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features point towards phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. The mousy odor is due to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body. Tyrosine hydroxylase deficiency and excess tetrahydrobiopterin cofactor are not associated with PKU. Excess phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is not a known condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mental retardation, microcephaly, and a mousy odor to the breath are characteristic symptoms of phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase activity, leading to a buildup of phenylalanine and its byproducts in the body. Options B, C, and D are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mental retardation and microcephaly suggest a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine. The mousy odor to his breath is due to the accumulation of phenylalanine. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including mental retardation, microcephaly, and mousy odor to breath, suggest a phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, which can lead to a buildup of phenylalanine and its byproduct phenylpyruvic acid in the body. Options B and C are not associated with these symptoms, and option D is a contradictory statement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mental retardation, microcephaly, and mousy odor are classic symptoms of phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. Option B, deficit of tyrosine hydroxylase activity, is not associated with these symptoms. Option C, excess tetrahydrobiopterin cofactor, is associated with hyperphenylalaninemia but not necessarily with the symptoms mentioned. Option D, excess phenylalanine hydroxylase activity, is not a known condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mental retardation, microcephaly, and a mousy odor to the breath are classic findings in patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. All other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Mental retardation, microcephaly, and a mousy odor are all symptoms of phenylketonuria (PKU), which is caused by a deficit of phenylalanine hydroxylase activity. Options B, C, and D are not related to PKU.
